unnormalised: Okay, folks, let’s talk finance. Specifically, the rollercoaster that is taking out a loan in India. It's like a Bollywood movie – drama, suspense, and a whole lot of colorful characters. I, your humble narrator, have starred in this film more times than I’d like to admit.
normalised: Okay, folks, let’s talk finance. Specifically, the rollercoaster that is taking out a loan in India. It's like a Bollywood movie – drama, suspense, and a whole lot of colorful characters. I, your humble narrator, have starred in this film more times than I’d like to admit.

unnormalised: First, there was the education loan. Me, fresh out of college, armed with a B.Com degree and dreams of conquering the corporate world (spoiler alert: that didn't happen right away). I needed ₹2000000 (that’s 20 lakh, for those playing at home). The bank manager, a stern gentleman with a mustache that could rival a walrus, grilled me for what felt like 3 hrs straight. He wanted to know everything – my family history, my career prospects, and whether I knew the difference between a fixed and floating interest rate. I barely knew the difference between chai and coffee at that point!
normalised: First, there was the education loan. Me, fresh out of college, armed with a B. Com degree and dreams of conquering the corporate world (spoiler alert: that didn't happen right away). I needed rupee two million (that’s twenty lakh, for those playing at home). The bank manager, a stern gentleman with a mustache that could rival a walrus, grilled me for what felt like three hours straight. He wanted to know everything – my family history, my career prospects, and whether I knew the difference between a fixed and floating interest rate. I barely knew the difference between chai and coffee at that point!

unnormalised: Then came the home loan. Ah, the dream of owning a 2 BHK flat in Mumbai! I found the perfect place for Rs. 1.5 crore, a cozy little space that was conveniently located next to a noisy construction site and a perpetually overflowing garbage bin. But hey, it was *mine*… well, the bank's for the next 25 years. The paperwork alone weighed more than my entire luggage allowance on an international flight. I think I signed my name at least 500 times, and half the documents were in legalese I couldn't understand even after 5 cups of chai.
normalised: Then came the home loan. Ah, the dream of owning a two B-H-K flat in Mumbai! I found the perfect place for rupees one point five crore, a cozy little space that was conveniently located next to a noisy construction site and a perpetually overflowing garbage bin. But hey, it was *mine*… well, the bank's for the next twenty five years. The paperwork alone weighed more than my entire luggage allowance on an international flight. I think I signed my name at least five hundred times, and half the documents were in legalese I couldn't understand even after five cups of chai.

unnormalised: And who can forget the personal loan? This one was a doozy. See, my cousin’s wedding was coming up, and you know how it is. Everyone expects you to show up looking like a Bollywood star, draped in gold and diamonds. My budget? Let’s just say it was closer to that of a struggling auto-rickshaw driver. So, I did what any self-respecting Indian would do – I took out a personal loan for ₹50000. The interest rate was higher than the Himalayas, but hey, I looked fabulous at the wedding!
normalised: And who can forget the personal loan? This one was a doozy. See, my cousin’s wedding was coming up, and you know how it is. Everyone expects you to show up looking like a Bollywood star, draped in gold and diamonds. My budget? Let’s just say it was closer to that of a struggling auto-rickshaw driver. So, I did what any self-respecting Indian would do – I took out a personal loan for rupee fifty thousand. The interest rate was higher than the Himalayas, but hey, I looked fabulous at the wedding!

unnormalised: The worst part? The loan offers keep flooding in. "Pre-approved for Rs. 10 Lakhs!", they scream. "Low interest rates!", they promise. It's like they know I'm financially irresponsible!
normalised: The worst part? The loan offers keep flooding in. "Pre-approved for rupees ten lakhs!", they scream. "Low interest rates!", they promise. It's like they know I'm financially irresponsible!

unnormalised: And the EMI reminders! Oh, the sweet, melodious sound of my bank balance dwindling every month. It’s a constant reminder of my past spending decisions and the walrus-mustached bank manager who probably predicted all this.
normalised: And the E-M-I reminders! Oh, the sweet, melodious sound of my bank balance dwindling every month. It’s a constant reminder of my past spending decisions and the walrus-mustached bank manager who probably predicted all this.

unnormalised: Moral of the story? Loans are like that one relative who always shows up uninvited to family functions. They're a necessary evil, but you gotta be careful not to let them take over your life (and your bank account).
normalised: Moral of the story? Loans are like that one relative who always shows up uninvited to family functions. They're a necessary evil, but you gotta be careful not to let them take over your life (and your bank account).

unnormalised: So, the next time you're considering taking out a loan, remember my tales of woe. Do your research, compare interest rates, and maybe, just maybe, try saving up a little first. Unless, of course, it's for a really, *really* good reason. Like a Bollywood-worthy wedding outfit. Just kidding! (Mostly.)
